Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2010 05:17PM Melanie36 wrote: Isn't there a special day (October I think) where everyone is supposed to practice their fire escape route? Well I think we should rally together and pick a date to stand on our front porches, outside our front doors, whatever, and shout as loud as we can "I HATE THIS F*CKING DISEASE!!!" Only being diagnosed in October I personally haven't lost a "sister" that I was really close with, but even hearing about people I am following or have gotten to know through this website that are getting sick is really upsetting...I dread the day I lose someone...I know it's only a matter of time... With Sympathy, Jennifer. Melanie

Posts.Content: Melanie36 wrote: WTF? I recently found out the horrible news and have been in a fog, robotically telling friends and family the same thing over and over. I've been reading some of the posts and I can't even begin to try and make sense of all the acronyms and stage #s and choices and what questions I'm supposed to ask. This is my life and I'm spposed to make sense of this all in a matter of a few days/weeks/months? All I know is that it is very large (over 5 cm or 2"), doesn't seem to be attached to the chest wall and they suspect it has spread to the lymph nodes. I've been waiting since last Tues. (Oct.6) to hear from the Breast Health Centre as to what next?? Biopsy/Lumpectomy/Mastectomy? Can anyone help me to sort all of this shit out. I'm 36, mother of 4 (18, 14, 6 and 3-all girls) and I'm scared...please help. :( Dx Nov.23/09 Stage IV Mets to liver IDC, DCIS GR.3 ER- PR- HER2 - Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2010 07:31PM Melanie36 wrote: Hey, Flachica, I was having the exact same pains as you were describing! Dx with liver mets end of Nov. started Xeloda at the end of Dec. around early Feb, I started getting those pains. I was told to take Tylenol 3s every few hours and not to wait for the pain to start. (preventing the pain is easier than trying to relieve it once it started) Dr.s couldn't really explain why I was having it, but said it could be related to the liver. I just got my 3 month scans done and apparently the 2 tumours in my lymph nodes and the numerous ones in my liver have gotten bigger, which to me explains the pain, discomfort. uuuggghhh. Glad you went on a trip, I've been traveling and plan on doing more in the future. It's amazing how much better I feel when I'm not at home surrounded by everything "Cancer"!! Melanie
Posts.Title: Newly dx’ed w/liver mets – question about drugs and ab pain flachica Melanie36

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2009 07:28PM Melanie36 wrote: Thank you ladies for all the info. Roseann your explanations allowed me to sigh for the first time in many days. I've been in shock since Tuesday and suprisingly quite unemotional. I guess it was the defense mechanisms b/c now all I want to do is cry. And I'm ANGRY. I know, I know denial, anger...I guess acceptance is next.  Yes I was told I have BC before doing a biopsy. They found it from my mammogram. It is 5 cm with a 1.5 cm appendage. I do have larger breasts (DD) and they don't believe it is attached to my chest wall, so I'm hoping lumpectomy is an option, although wouldn't a full mastectomy be the safest thing to do? They can have my lymph nodes. I'm just really struggling with the thought of losing my breasts and hair. Please keep in touch, Melanie Your words and information are invaluable. I couldn't imagine having to do this alone.
Posts.Title: 36, dx 6 days ago and so many questions... Melanie36 melissa-5-19

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2010 07:37PM Melanie36 wrote: konakat, Your news....SUCKS.... There are a few sayings that I have read and that have stuck. I save them for special people/moments like this: "I can't believe the cancer picked you...I feel sorry for the cancer!" You enjoy your wine, cake AND ice cream. If anybody even looks at you cross-eyed you tell them,"You just worry about yourself, I've already got cancer!" Hugs, honey, Melanie
Posts.Title: Progression in liver and bones :-( konakat dreamwriter

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2010 11:23PM Melanie36 wrote: Deb, Loved your rant Love and respect to ALL my sisters (and brothers-just found out a male co-worker of mine was dx with BC 3 years ago...) One of my favourites is..."At least they caught it early...no, actually the big tumour had time to have a little brother tumour and he decided to go play in another sandbox (my liver) before they figured it out." One other one..."Oh my sister's cousin's, best friend's, neighbour has BC and she still goes to work 7 days a week-while on chemo."...Well yipee! I hate her already. This is called Lance Armstronging-we're not all going to win the tour de France 150 times while in treatment. When people tell me they don't know what to say, I tell them "that's okay...it's better than saying something dumb!!!" I want people to tell me that they love me and are here for me...and then actually be there for me. I have cancer not cooties. Melanie
Posts.Title: RESPECTING the STAGE threads **RANT** cherneski Nico1012

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2010 11:52AM Melanie36 wrote: Thanks everyone, Texas was awesome, it was the best "Life Distraction" I've had in a while. The wedding was beautiful, held at a Bed and Breakfast just north of Austin. After the speech to the groom, my Aunt got up and said on behalf of the Bride and Groom they wanted to have a moment of silence and prayer for her niece/grooms cousin (me!!) because I was dealing with a very terrible disease and could use all the positive energy I could get. Well....I of course was not expecting this and burst into tears. It was very emotional. I mean for them to take time out of their special day to acknowledge what I am going through was amazing.(Although, to be honest, I could have done without the next half an hour of people sharing their stories of mothers, friends etc. who had breast cancer, took chemo and are fine now. Just made me want to scream "YAH, BUT I"M STAGE IV!!!!" I start Taxoterrible on Monday. But I'll have to have it done peripherally the first time. I've opted for the once every three weeks. I live a bit out of town from the cancer centre, but I'm open to the once a week thing if they can coordinate it with my weekly stage IV support group meetings. Heatherpalm-I hope I tolerate it half as well as you did. oh and it's Disney World. Lisa- I can't wait to dance with NED. Yan-I'm glad to hear Olga is up and around now. I hate being a part of the Xeloda Floppers Club, especially since it didn't work and I went through all that pain and peeling for nothing. Jeanne46, Elizabeth, ElaineD, Dreamwriter, Jean, Padiddle- as much as I would love to delay chemo, I've already delayed it once for these 2 trips (thinking I was going to continue Xeloda) so Dr. does not want to delay anymore. Since Disney is during week 2, he thinks I should be over the "worst of it". I picked up my free wig and head coverings from the "Guardian Angel" room at our Cancer Centre today. The wig wouldn't be my first pick but it was all they had that was remotely close to my natural hair and it looked the best. I think I'll still buy one from the wig place, though. I'm not sure I'm ready for this phase. Some women shave it off well before hand, others have head shaving parties, with family involved, and yet others wait until it falls out on it's own...I guess I'll have to take it day by day and decide then. Melanie
Posts.Title: I've got crappy news as well Melanie36 Melanie36

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2010 11:16AM Melanie36 wrote: Hey Cat, This sucks doesn't it. Throughout my cancer journey, I seem to be hitting worst case scenario at every step. When am I going to get a break and get some good news??? I'm so sorry to hear about your hubby. This isn't fair. You vent all you want, that's what we're here for. On a different note, I just returned from Austin and loved it. Texas was awesome. It was a nice "life distraction". Melanie
Posts.Title: Does it get any worse than this? cmhartley Padiddle

Posts.Content: Melanie36 wrote: Well, the Xeloda didn't work. The tumours in my lymph nodes have almost doubled in size compared to my scans in November. It's funny because when I started chemo Christmas eve, they were large and swollen, and they feel like they are smaller and they are less painful. My Onc wants to start me on Taxotere. I don't know the first thing about this drug and/or it's side effects, and am really mad at how this is going to change my day to day life. I've been given the option to take it once a week or once every 3 weeks. The latter is more convenient, but the former would probably be less harsh on my body? Any suggestions? Regardless of my results today  I am flying to Texas for my cousin's wedding tomorrow and am determined to use our booked vacation package to Disney on the 23rd. I'm a little worried though. I don't think Mickey will like it if I puke all over his shoes. And Cinderella might question my parenting when I'm face first in my breakfast because I'm so tired. According to the calendar I will lose my hair while at Disney. Great. This sucks, thanks for listening, Melanie Dx Nov.23/09 Stage IV Mets to liver IDC, DCIS GR.3 ER- PR- HER2 - Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: I've got crappy news as well Melanie36 Melanie36

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2010 11:48AM Melanie36 wrote: Yan, I was so sorry to see your post about Olga. I think about you both often. We're both Canadian, stage IV, triple negative AND on Xeloda only. This disease is so individual, it's comforting to have people who "know exactly what you are going through".  I can't seem to offer you any advice any different from the others. I know the feeling of discovering something "new". Every headache stirs up thoughts of brain mets, every ache reminds me of the possibility of bone mets, and after being winded after climbing 6 stairs, I push away thoughts of lung mets. I just have to remind my self to take it day by day. I will be starting my second cycle of Xeloda on Thursday and had enjoyed my "week off". (days 12-14 were getting rather uncomfortable.) I cannot tell if this hockey puck floating in my left breast is any smaller, but my lymph nodes in my armpit aren't as swollen or tender. And as of this second, my feet aren't hot and burning, dry or hard, so today is a good day. I fired my Onc (long story-but he had the bedside manner of an aardvark) and I am looking forward to meeting my new one. Keep us posted, passing along (((HUGS))), Melanie

You are a wonderful writer, and I followed a similar format to yours and would have loved to use some of your lines but who wants to plagiarize a letter to a boob, lol!!! Thank you again, I will read this out loud to my breasts the morning of my surgery on Nov. 24. Melanie

Posts.Title: Six Things You Shouldn't Say to a Cancer Patient EnglishMajor RobinWendy

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2010 09:55AM Melanie36 wrote: HI Gina, I was dx with mets to liver 14 hours before bi lat mastectomy. This was in Nov. I, too have had problems with my onc. He's been around the block several times and is quite respected in the "cancer community" as a researcher and "knows his stuff". That very well may be, but if research is his thing, then I say put on a lab coat and sit your a$$ behind a microscope because you have no business speaking to your patients in a patronizing, I am GOD tone of voice!! After 2 appointments, I contacted the patient representative at our Cancer Care facility and was quickly transferred to another onc. She did recommend that I write Mr. Meanie a letter as a "teaching tool" for him to better understand how he made his patient feel...I'm still trying to get the courage to write such a letter... It is very encouraging to hear all the long term success stories!! Melanie

Posts.Title: Well, I finally made my announcement at work... Fitztwins ShirleyHughes

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2010 11:59AM Melanie36 wrote: Makmak3030, I have to agree with Jan125, the stats are outdated. I was dx'd in early Oct. and just hours before my scheduled surgery in late Nov., I was informed that there was a large cluster of lesions on my liver-surgery was canceled-I was now stage IV. Of course I was terrified, I knew what this meant and immediately had this uncontrollable fear that I wouldn't even make a year. The women on this board have been an inspiration and are helping me to overcome this fear. I can't remember where I read this quote but it has stuck with me... "Last time I checked the bottom of my foot, there was no expiry date." Fitztwins, who is a regular poster on this site also said something powerful and has stuck with me. "I don't believe in stats, never asked after my second year ... I read something once. There are lies, damn lies, and stats... Seriously, some of us will live 2-3 years with mets. Some of us will live 5, 7, 10, 17 + years...we ALL have to believe we will be in the 10+ year club." Love her. About the pain...I'm not a doctor, but one thing I learned was that not every pain and ache is related to the cancer. This was a very hard concept for me to accept and I kind of abandoned my regular doctor for several months after my dx. Remember the Oncs deal with all things cancer related. If you are having pain and he/she says it's not related, then I would go to my regular Dr. and ask. I've been having these horrible pains at the top of my stomache  where the ribcage meets. After telling several of my friends about it, 2 or 3 times I've heard people say it sounds like it could be my gallbladder. They're not Dr.s either, but it reinforced the fact that Dr.s all have specialties and that your Onc can't be expected to dx everything. My CT scan also showed that I have a kidney stone and polyps on my uterus...so I'm just waiting for those things to flare up on me...lol. Being HER2+ you do have the option of Herceptin as another piece of ammo. Myself being HER2-, I'm holding out for these PARP inhibitors currently in clinical trials that are showing lots of promise for us triple negs. So many new treatments ARE coming along...I'm hanging in there for these and for many other reasons Hugs, Melanie
